Description: Rusty grey, slightly bent, rectangular metal cigarette box with a lid and part of the paper label. One side of the box is now open. The lid was originally hinged, however, the hinges are now broken off the box. The paper label on the lid is very colourful with a depiction of a bare-breasted woman smoking a cigarette. She is surrounded by mounds of fabric or cushions and wears a gold coloured necklace and headveil with gold coins along the edge. Pharaonic style columns and a cornice are visible in the background on the left side. The box is originally from Cairo. The labels on the sides show palm trees while the ones on the end advertise the product (100 cigarettes, format petit), its origin (Cairo, Egypt) and manufacturer (Aravanopoulos & Cie)
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Kulubnarti, 21-S-43 House 1, Room 1 Lower Level
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2006, London, BM, Gallery 61, 'Kulubnarti' 2007 9 Mar-3 Sept, Belgium, Musee Royal de Mariemont, 'Pharaons noirs Sur la Piste des Quarante Jours'
Condition: Paper label is fragile, box is rusty.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Dr William Yewdale Adams
Donated by: W S Webb Museum of Anthropology (University of Kentucky)
Additional IDs: Excavation/small finds number: 85.8.63 (excavation object cat. no.)
